commentBody: Final-round voting on the 2025 Griddy Awards is underway until 11:59 PM on January 25. You can find the ballot here: https://form.jotform.com/260166070446150 John Ezra, Marshall Walthew and I were pleased to see so many votes for the nominated puzzles. The final round ballot is much shorter than the first round ballot ‚Äî there are five finalists in four categories. The puzzle descriptions are meant to simply remind you of the puzzle. We hope you‚Äôll find the ballot user-friendly. If you have any trouble with it, comment here. One of us will see it. Thanks for voting!

Impressive puzzle. 

If you didn‚Äôt like it, I recommend checking out the revealer. 

(Also appropriate advice for those who rage about rebuses on Thursday)

The one thing I didn‚Äôt say when I finished this puzzle was Eww!

A very nifty puzzle, Rena.

Quite a fun puzzle!  I love the wit of the 'yoo' answers.  I very nearly had a cheat free puzzle, but... I had 'GAG' for  'hilarious thing' , not  GAS.  And yes,  ('get lists' doesn't make as much sense as SET LISTS.)  But...

Thank you for a lovely start to the week!

I didn‚Äôt even realize at first that AFTER MATTHEW was part of the theme set.  Oh, ‚ÄúAFTERMATH‚Äù,  good one!

And it took me a minute to realize that the trick of THE SETTLERS OF YUCATAN derives from the board game ‚ÄúCATAN‚Äù.  

Flyspecked to change GAg to GAS. I knew gETLISTS looked wrong.   

Nicely done, Rena. Yew outdid yourself!

This was so good!!!!

The puns OMG. I aspire to be able to think of stuff like this. Kudos to Rena. Really loved this crossword. There were moments where we got a bit frustrated but when we figured it out then we realised "OH THAT MAKES A LOT OF SENSE AND OMG NICE". A great crossword. You should be proud of yourself.

Caitlin describes this puzzle as having a "classic Sunday trick," and I agree. The entries are fresh, but the "trick" is more than twice the age of the constructor. Well done, Rena! (Drove past your campus last month.)

[One of the 105D Levys tweaking the script]




EUGENE EDITING
Me? Yes, I loved the puzzle ‚Äî but what cracked me up was the last sentence of Caitlin‚Äôs commentary. I mean, it was hilarious!
Some might get a chuckle that my first attempt for "Like the Gospel of Mark" was OFTENSATHRU

This was very clever and apart from the theme I thought it was a decent challenge for a Sunday. I especially loved TWO AND A HALF MENU. Here‚Äôs a few more I came up with:

Top fishing spot in Louisiana? BEST BAYOU
Illustrated Mark Twain edition? PHOTO FINN ISSUE
Butler who‚Äôs not quite in the right place? ASKEW JEEVES
Make some suggestions in the game of Clue? ACCUSE MURDERERS
‚ÄúSounds like a you problem‚Äù is a phrase I should use more often. Thanks!

When the theme dawned on me, slowly, steadily, as a good theme should, I was just grinning from EAR to ear. Settlers of YuCatan was my giveaway and the bonus was that it took me back to the days when Catan was our favorite family game. So much to admire about your construction, Rena!  Congratulations on your first Sunday, and here‚Äôs a hope there will be more to come.

Fun puzzle and theme! I had more of a "ni" problem than a "you" problem‚Äînot so much because of the knights who say "ni"‚Äî though they are quite a pestilence upon our land, not to mention the passing ruffians who say it to old ladies at will.... Sad days, indeed.

Sorry, I digressed again, my problem with "ni" was the word SniTS instead of SPATS over at 85A. I do not know violin speak, nor am I strong in the Star Trek prequels. (Please don't yell too hard at me if that's the wrong terminology. I just couldn't really get into the earlier episodes that were really the later episodes or vice versa.) 

Anyhow, so I got the horse feathers message and considered doing a check puzzle because I hate looking for errors on Sunday, but since that was my last area to complete and I was pretty sure everything else was likely okay, I looked there and played around.

Yes, yes...  UnBOW could just as easily be UPBOW and I suppose NABOO as likely as NiBOO. So there we are with happy music and a gold star that I think I'll keep all for myself.... I'm very selfish like that.

Got closer to finishing this than any other Sunday, but still about 10 clues short. And that took almost 2 hours.

As usual, did not see the theme and didn‚Äôt even realise there was a theme until reading the column.

Overall a fair challenge for my level. Considering the long entries there were very few answers that seemed they‚Äôd been bashed in to shape to make them fit, very well put together.

That was a lot of fun. Very impressive,  Rena.
However, if you find yourself having to flyspeck at the end and you're not particularly college sports-minded, 110 Across is YEP not YEs and 111 Down is PITT not sITT

Finally got the theme with the last theme clue I sussed out ‚Äî men/u. 

I enjoyed this puzzle ‚Äî and the variety of phonetic presentations!

Thank you, as always, for the cognitive calisthenics.

ILOVEDIT.

Got AFTERMATTHEW first of the theme entries, noticed the phonetic u, confirmed the theme by entering THESETTLERSOFYUCATAN, and giggled quite a bit. 

Had GAg before GAS (I see I'm not alone) but gETLISTS didn't work. Otherwise pretty good wavelength for clues. Having played violin helped ... I didn't know VOILE (or DINKS) but dredged it up from somewhere in the recesses of my memory.
Dinks got me.
Meh
the theme shouldnt find me twiddling my thumbs and yawning after solving the puzzle, should it?

Can't decide between casting Dancy, Grant or Jackman?
Sounds like a Hugh problem.

Nice debut Sunday puzzle, Rena. Managed to catch on to the tricky business about halfway through. Enjoyed the theme answers, not a TWINGE of regret.

Thanks!
The first Sunday crossword puzzle I‚Äôve finished without looking anything up!
anyone else think the mini was super hard?!
Did anyone else notice the Bruce Willis double bill at 4D and 59D?
Bit of a ‚Äúdating‚Äù theme to the week was it.  Maybe I will eventually lock Nth into the memory‚Ä¶

My next door neighbor uses the phrase ‚ÄúSOUNDS LIKE A YOU PROBLEM‚Äù on a regular basis (not necessarily directed at me, but in relaying stories about work) ü§£ 
We binge watched Schitt‚Äôs Creek during Covid. Funniest show I‚Äôve seen in a long time. Lots of talent in that LEVY family! I think it‚Äôs time to rewatch the series ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Thank you, Rena. Fantastic Sunday grid ü§©

Well, I almost made it to the end without cheating - but I had to surrender on the very final clue.

The heck is a VOILE?

What a delight! I loved loved loved this gem of a puzzle! So cute ü•∞üòçüòò

Um, no.

A trivia-heavy grid? Check. A punny theme with a phonetic element? Check. I've never liked any Rena Cohen puzzle yet, even when she was not channeling John Kugelman.

I actually figured out the theme, only to find it groans worthy.

As for the fill... I tried to solve this puzzle unaided but ultimately I needed not only lookups (the closed-off area with CHAIO, TEMU, and ACT clued arcanely as yet another American exam) but also a check of the puzzle - a few crosses were beyond cruel for me, including YE_ ("Roger that!") and _ITT ("The Panthers of the A.C.C."). I put an S there, resulting in YES/SITT, which looks good if you have no idea what the Panthers, the ACC or Pitt are ü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è.

Also, while ENTREE in an American context is an instant gimme, and I know how this meaning of the word arose, I still find it very strange, especially when clued as something following a *starter*...

(It's day 16510 of my having never used the word "delightful" - or it's Polish equivalent - other than in jest, ironically, or to describe a dog)

I liked the theme, but I particularly enjoyed some of the wordplay in some of the regular clues. I could stand to see more "this and this, but not this," though, and less DRS and OWOW. Those always feel like placeholders to me.

Ahhh...starting to see my problem now - the puzzle title doesn't appear at the top of the puzzle but only when I click on info which I don't do until I solve or reveal the puzzle. That's what I'm telling myself anyway! ;>]
Real issue is that some answers are beyond my regional domain or areas of interest like names of authors. That challenge plus figuring out revealers makes it a poor experience for me. I'm really intrigued by solvers untroubled by any of it.
No‚Ä¶there are no eels in our pie and mash!

Motto of an indigenous Iditarod team

I‚ÄôM INUIT TO WIN IT
Didn't get the gimmick for the longest time but I finally did! Not a bad puzzle but I had no idea what "The Settlers of Catan" was. I had to look it up (afterwards).

Congratulations on your first Sunday, Rena. I liked them all, but UNITES IN SHINING ARMOR was a favorite. The variety of ways to achieve the "U" sound and the placement, sometimes up front, sometimes at the end, was a nice extra. Now I have GEORGIA on my mind. Willie style: https://youtu.be/YMxdr78y-E4?si=-Iz1Gh7aF_-rzdQb
Can't say I was a fan of the mini this morning.

Two excellent revealers.  SOUNDS LIKE A YOU PROBLEM has a fresh ring, and the title ‚ÄúUse Your Words‚Äù perfectly encapsulates what the theme does ‚Äì YOOsifying words.

I like that the yoo sound is represented five ways ‚Äì EW, IEW, YU, U (used twice), and UE, and that it is echoed in MALAMUTE.

BONSAI looks and sounds beautiful, and trips off beautiful images in my head.  NABOO looks and sounds silly; it warms my heart because it‚Äôs the kind of word my older sister and I made up as kids, and worked to death, making up sentences that included it.

PITT ‚Äì With ‚ÄúThe‚Äù, in the beginning of its second season, and I‚Äôm as hooked as I was in the first.

Serendipity watch.  Both meanings of DOUGH back-to-back: Yesterday‚Äôs [Dough at a taqueria] for PESOS, and today‚Äôs [It might raise a bunch of dough] for YEAST.  Also, today‚Äôs NW has two list-shorteners: EST and a backward ETTAL (close enough).

Fun, brain-loving resistance, memories, and sparkling wordplay ‚Äì a lovely box to unwrap.  Thank you, Rena!

Riffing off @Vaer‚Äôs brilliant ‚ÄúSounds like a Hugh problem‚Äù

‚ÄúJackman‚Äôs first love who drove an econobox made by Zastava Automobiles‚Äù

HUGHSYUGOGIRL

‚ÄúWhat she said when he became too possessive‚Äù

HUGHYOUDONTOWNME

‚ÄúWhich led to . . .‚Äù

YOUGOHUGH

9D presents a case where technically precise and general usages conflict, annoying users of the former.
Consider, pardon the maths, ‚Äúpolynomials of the n-th degree have general algorithmic solutions for n=1,2,3,4.‚Äù In none of these cases would I consider n to have a ‚Äúhigh‚Äù value.
But, as has been remarked many times previously, common usage also has status in NYT xwords.
1A. After completing today‚Äôs xword, I next worked on Sat July 6, 2002 .  15A [Royal topper] DIADEM

This puzzle's wordplay was pretty lame, not all of them making sense. Could you please explain THESETTELERSOFYUCATAN? What's the play there? And SOUNDSLIKEAYOUPROBLEM is a phrase I've used many times, where's the wordplay. Please explain.
Lovely puzzle, satisfying and fun. My partner giggling and giving me ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs TWOANDAHALFMENU‚Äù will be a rush that lasts a lifetime
Meh
Fun puzzle, congrats to Rena on the successful Sunday debut! 'Sounds like a you problem' is a great idea for a theme, and it delivered.
I loved this puzzle but was unable to quite get it until I read the tricky clues Colin and then- gold star!!!!
I enjoyed it. 118 across should have two Ns to be correct. But ambitious debut and nice overall.

Whew. And Wow. Was really puzzled for quite a while but finally catching on to the trick was just a huge turning point, and it was a ton of fun pondering and working out all the theme answers after that. Pretty impressive to come up with all those answers. And - one puzzle find today. Nothing really amazing but just kind of cute. A Monday from November 5, 2012 by Andrea Carla Michaels. One theme clue and answer: "Wynken's fishing buddies" BLYNKENANDNOD And you could probably guess the clues for the other three theme answers: LARRYANDCURLY DEWEYANDLOUIE CRACKLEANDPOP Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/5/2012&g=43&d=A ....

Good photo choice, Caitlin, it gave me a smile.

Only minor difficulty was at the crossing of MAMI and CHAO. 63A, an endearment for mother could be any combination of Ms and vowels. 51D, I knew she was Mitch's wife, but could not remember the name. Chao, Cheo, Chio, Choo, Chuo ? Seemed like any vowel could do!

Excellent puzzle, Rene.
So many fun moments in this one. Best Sunday in a while. Well done!

First, the stinker:  54D "Loses freshness."  WILTS, DROOPS, SPOILS, DISCOLORS, MOLDS, AGES, GOES OFF, CURDLES,...we COULD go on, and guess what? We would never say, write, or think STALES.  When your bread dries out, it's still not STALE, but it's a good time to make French toast, like we did this morning.  
There are many things that *do* GO STALE, like songs, jokes, and some foods--though there are edibles such as broccoli that go limp and lose freshness... but we do not say, "The broccoli is STALE."  We just toss it or steam it anyway and serve it up with butter, lemon juice, and a guilty smile.  Cough cough.

Other than that, clever, fun, and finished--just what one wants a puzzle to be on a Sunday morning --if possible, with French toast, butter and maple syrup, and fresh fruit.

Great puzzle, Rena! Lots of unique and fun clueing, and very few (if any) Naticks. I loved all the extra-long answers that gave me an extra workout on a relaxing Sunday morning. 

I noticed something interesting: At the southwest corner, 122A could easily have been [‚Äú1 star‚Äù]: IHATEDIT with small tweaks to the clues for 104D [Colorful banded rock] and 116D [D√≠a de ___ Madres]. 115D would have worked as clued, since they‚Äôre both AHs!
For 75A "Dove's dwelling" - I pointed toward my window and said "right there!".  A bunch of mourning doves like to hang out on the window ledge during cold days.

Fun theme, Rena. It was below my average but I am in no rush on this snowy Sunday to go anywhere. The old magazine puzzle section puzzles before the days of internet help often took me most of the week and often had an unsolved space that I had to wait all week to find out.
First Sunday puzzle? Rena, you done good! Great mix of clues. Grazie!

Sure I'm curious about the theme and whether or not I'll like it.  I have PROBLEM at the end of one theme answer and ARMOR at the end of the other.  Will this be clever and fun?

But there's no way around it.  I cannot find out without dealing with trivia nonsense like home planets in Star Wars and Instagram posts and a rock band and discontinued IPods and I just don't wanna.

I did the Cryptic instead.  Instead of tiny little squibs of useless information, every answer was its own exercise in deduction and puzzle-solving acumen.  I found this one very easy for a Cryptic at the top and crunchy at the bottom.  Had to cheat on 3 clues to finish.  Looked up synonyms for one word in each clue for 16D and 20A.  Used Anagram Solver to get 5D.

Unlike cheating on a regular puzzle, cheating on a Cryptic requires skill.  You have to know WHAT to look up.  Old hands at Cryptics may be able to guess what I looked up for those three clues.  Non-Cryptic solvers won't have the slightest idea.

This one's easier than many Cryptics and it plays very fair, which many Cryptics don't.  I recommend it.
There are WAY too many proper nouns in the grid today. I count at least 3 naticks, where in a well constructed puzzle there should be zero. (Barry's probably going to get mad at me again...)
This was so much fun! I really enjoyed when the theme answers came together.

This was a classic classic puzzle! So delightful!(I would have said "entertaining", but Andrzej.)

Talk about perseverance! Rena Cohen spent half her life after her first submission waiting for her first acceptance! Rena, I bow down to you(because I don't know how to upbow)!

I loved this puzzle! One of those magical ones where I was on the same wavelength as the constructor and everything just flowed. I don‚Äôt normally pay much attention to times, but I checked after this one, and sure, it‚Äôs my PB for a Sunday: 13:24. 

Hit the ground running right from 1A. I was delighted when I realized the theme and it was fun to see how it played out across each themed answer. And 59D made me laugh, as I‚Äôm currently sitting at my gate waiting to fly there. Thank you for the delightful puzzle.
Two references to Settlers of Catan in a row! Love it!
Super fun Sunday. Loved the cluing for UPBOW in particular üéª
Outstanding, thanks Rena!
With no disrespect to the Dalai Lama, I could not remember how to spell Dalai.

[One of those ‚ÄúSchitt‚Äôs Creek‚Äù Levys tweaking the script]




EUGENE EDITING
Rena, I loved solving this puzzle.  It was fun, entertaining and witty.

A near-first for me: the revealer helped me solve the theme entries.  It's far more common that I struggle through a puzzle until it is complete, and only then see the cleverness that glued them together.

And then I read that Ms. Cohen submitted her first puzzle at age 9.  I'm about 60 years older than that and still haven't the courage to face the icy stare of Will Shortz with my own submission.  Also, the "#1 spot in London?" !  Blimey!

Eels?!

Those sound like the worst pies in London.


(Look, I made a mash.)
such a clever puzzle, great job! a nice hungover sunday morning solve.

Because I really never grew up, when I saw the clue for 96A, I immediately thought LOO, but dismissed it because.... 

I laughed out loud a few seconds later when I the crosses confirmed my juvenile first guess.

Solved without look ups, and faster than my normal, all without really getting the theme. I knew the theme had something to do with the ‚ÄúU‚Äù sound but even after reading the Wordplay I still am not entirely sure about the theme.
How unsurprising to find the ugly expression "Bete noire" in 2026 NYT.
Good puzzle, but dink shots are not a thing, they are drop shots.  The obscure internet reference won't help.

XWSTATS: "You solved this 0:03 (0.2%) faster than your average Sunday time."
Me: WAAAY TOO EASY!!!!
Seriously though, I now aspire to finish a puzzle EXACTLY on my average time for a day! (No cheating and checking my average time beforehand though....)
Enjoyed it! But without knowing DIADEM or LEAH immediately I had mEAt or no mEAt, then mEAL or no mEAL, then - finally - DEAL or no DEAL. They all made sense to me!
Re Pie and mash: beef is not a fish. I think someone is making stuff up here.
The OAR / STEIG / NOIRE crossings really stumped me. I‚Äôm still not getting the ‚Äúmight come with a shell‚Äù clue?

Nice puzzle! Pretty simple theme and for me it was a quicker solve than usual.

More of us need to be ok with "this puzzle didn't match my knowledge" and remember that this doesn't mean it was too hard or unfair. It happens! The stars do or don't align.
A fun solve but had to throw in the towel at 1A; absolutely no clue on that one.   As the matriarch I wonder if LEAH sported a DIADEM?

Great puzzle, but if the NYT really wants me to "share my thoughts", these are them: I'm finding it more and more difficult to enjoy crosswords. 

Each day I first turn to the news, and read about the military occupation of cities, ICE shooting ordinary people, individuals being pulled out of their homes or from their place of work, and maybe never heard from again.

Some people tell me that I'm lucky to be living in Canada, but many Canadians are not feeling particularly safe today, just because there is a border. That means nothing, if Trump or one of his "kids" wants to retaliate for whatever reason and send troops to Toronto or Montreal or where? -- Winnipeg? Thunder Bay? Halifax?. Maybe there will be some justification given regarding fentanyl or terrorist cells, or critical resources. And I'm sure our prime minister will be concerned, as he always is, but I fear that that may be the extent of what our government would do about it. 

I love NYT crosswords, I love the puns, I love reading the comments in wordplay. But it's getting harder and harder to block out the rest.

I thought this was terrific. Loved answers like ‚ÄúSettlers of Yucat√°n‚Äù and ‚ÄúSounds like a you problem.‚Äù The hardest one for me to get was the wedding - I kept thinking it had to be a version of ‚ÄúrITESINSHININGARMOR,‚Äù which doesn‚Äôt fit the spaces, nor the theme. I was almost blank in the NE for quite a while because I had mdS, then considered rnS before settling on DRS because ANNARBOR just had to be right. 
Then, there was the kind of answer I dislike intensely, I had Ouch, then OWie, then finally OWOW. It just feels like lazy, manipulative cluing, not a real, ‚Äúright‚Äù answer. Same when we are faced with Czar one time and Tsar the next. Or Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa, without any way of differentiating without crosses. I was also tripped up by having sITT for PITT for a long time. 

Who is the third LEVY? I knew Eugene and Dan were in S Creek.

Culture clash today. Except I got RBI again!

Way, way beyond me. I just didn't know enough, the theme solutions and the YOU PROBLEM phrase were like a foreign language. 

Of course I did solve quite a few clues, not enough too solve the others with crossers - and none of the proper nouns; from ACT to PITT ... I was lost, (although I looked them up). The only one that I couldn't find was PSA (prostate-specific-antigen can't be right) and public service announcement and 'brain on drugs' doesn't make sense either.
Very nice puzzle! Got to tell the constructor about this game, though: https://strongholdgames.com/our-games/diamonds/ :)

Fun and tricky all wrapped up into one. I had an aura without pain 2 weeks ago and it terrified me. The write-up and linked article about them spooked me even more with the description of it being when "neurons stop firing and go quiet". I've felt like I've been missing a few brain cells since... grateful for these puzzles to try to revive them and keep them going.

After too many years to admit, I hit my Sunday goal by controlling my urge to hop around a filled grid looking for an incorrect answer. I took a breath and started reviewing across answers one by one from start to finish. I had a few suspicions but went on to check the downs without being distracted. 

Zeroed in on 59 down, Vegas, and realized we were talking about Las Vegas which was my home for a few years. Boom! Done!

As a newbie (noob), Sundays and Mondays are my favorites. I enjoyed this one. My only pedantic point is 100A. I've never seen a traveling warning. It's a violation and turnover, if called.  But thank the maker for sports clues!
Really enjoyed this puzzle from the punny theme answers to the wording of the clues, which felt fresh, not just the usual stand-by phrases. Great job Rena!
I would question the cluing for 22-Across. As a student at the University of Michigan in the late 60s, early 70s, we referrred to Ann Arbor as A-Squared. Never heard of the nickname "A".

Memorable moments before and after my solve.

Spent a few seconds before starting, just admiring the grid design. Doing this would never have occurred to me before I started coming here for the comments.

Afterwards, even though I'd gotten the puzzle in my usual Sunday time with happy music on the first try, reading Caitlin's article got my ego back down to a much more modest, and appropriate, level. Sounds as though she got the theme during her first pass through the across clues? Whaaa? Wonder how many of you experts did that. On my first pass, I left all kinds of gaps because I knew something was going on but didn't know what. As with Minesweeper, I just step around those places.

During the solve, reached 68D with the dots and laughed out loud. 'Cause, DOTS.

At the end, I had two squares blank: YE_ because I wasn't confident it was a P, and the cross between TE_U and MA_I because, well, I had absolutely no idea. Guessed the P for Pittsburgh and then figured I'd start with an M for the affectionate term because other languages do that. And hey, both guesses were right today.

Another case where knowledge gets in the way. The gospel of Mark is the oldest according to most scholars, so it can't come AFTER one of the others. But of course that's not the order in the Bible.

Enjoyable puzzle. Annoyed at myself for having MAMI and then changing it because I misremembered the cabinet secretary as CHOO. Fortunately the comments straightened me out.

When I get stuck, it‚Äôs almost always somewhere other than the ‚Äòtricky clues‚Äô.  

Today it was at the YEP/PITT intersection, where I had an S instead of a P.  SITT doesn‚Äôt mean anything to me, but neither did PITT until I gave up and looked it up.

Silence is golden, but duct tape is silver.

Did youse like this puzzle as much as I did? I hope so. STALE as a verb, not so much, unless you're talking about a snowboard grab, AKA stalefish.

Every Sunday I look forward to the NYT Xword puzzle and every Sunday I am usually disappointed in the quality of the puzzle, when compared to older ones.

This puzzle was no exception and pretty boring to solve.
Two days in a row where CATAN (a game I'd never before) has been included in the crossword. Is the NYT getting paid for product placement?

This was a fine, accessible Sunday for me. I came in well under average, though I did get caught up on the COTE/STALES area for a while because I'm not very familiar with COTE, and I never use STALES as a verb in that way (it is in the dictionary). I also had to flyspeck for a misspelling or two. 
 
Maybe as much as the puzzle itself, I enjoy the word controversies in the comments and how they lead me to learn new etymologies and current and past usages.

Absolutely loved this theme. Well done! I laughed out loud at DOTS, and just so many good clues throughout. Schitts Creek and the LEVYs mentioned!!! üôåüèº My favorite comfort show. Thanks for a truly enjoyable puzzle, Rena!

You could definitely tell it was a constructor on the younger side. Starbucks drinks. Star Wars prequel reference (Queen Amidala) and never heard of anyone refer to a ‚Äúbeastie.‚Äù

But workable even for us oldsters!
Didn't know Shrek! was a book! Passed the morning merrily doing this crossword. Thanks, constructor!
i think this was the first sunday puzzle i did without using the wordplay column! i had a lot of fun with it, especially the theme. i loved the theme answers. great job!
Not even close. I liked the theme, but ACT, CHAO, MAMI, and TEMU beat me down. And that was with guessing at the hard tennis shot that catches flies.

Last Monday I had an hour long, two medico (M.D. and specialist) appointment, plus down the gullet procedure, then to T.J. for grocery shopping.

Tues: Semiannual dental appt, teeth cleaning.  Driver side door failed to unlock (had to crawl over gearshift to exit passenger side).

Wed: M.R.I. (old folks taxi courtesy of city program)

Thurs:  Arranged door lock failure assessment, med. follow-up. Placed mega Costco grocery delivery order.
 
Fri:  Drove car to mechanic (door failed to shut and swung open on the way, dealt with it, but had to crawl over gear shift again to exit). Listened to mansplaining about how door locks work (I said I have driven this car for more than 20 years and know how they work). Imperfect solution to intermittent lock failure.  (Fingers crossed)

Every day: Worked the Crossword, Connections, Wordle, Strands, Letterbox puzzles, Watched PBS news, network news, Jeopardy, the remainder of Dr. Zhivago dvd. and Warriors games, when available.

I am grateful that I can still do all of this, but I get a little worn out sometimes. More medico stuff to come.

GRIDDY BALLOT TEMPORARILY DISABLED

I disabled the Griddy Awards Final Round Ballot a little after 2 PM Mountain Time because Puzzlemucker caught a mistake. (Thank you, sir.)

Either I will reactivate the ballot for which I published the link yesterday (first comment on the Sunday puzzle) or I'll create a revised ballot and publish a new link. 

If you try to vote and get a message that the ballot is unavailable, please try again later. If that doesn't work, there's a revised ballot with a different link.

I haven't yet looked to see what I did wrong yesterday. But:

‚Ä¢ Whatever the mistake is, it's my fault. John Ezra and Marshall Walthew had not seen the ballot when I published the link.

‚Ä¢ I will fix it. The worst-case scenario is that I delete the 29 votes cast so far and those people will have to vote again. I'll try to fix it some other way because I don't want anyone who has already voted to miss the notification that their ballot has been discarded.

Again, please accept my apology.
OMG. What a wonderful theme.

I am well familiar with the particularly pedantic or snobbish bent of many of the commenters here, but I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle, and reading so many complaints was mystifying to me. I couldn't help but enjoy the irony, given 67A. I could just use that as my reply to all of them.

Thank you, Rena, for such a fabulous Sunday theme -- as 122A states: I LOVED IT! 

It's particularly impressive that you even have the time to construct such a strong grid (or ANY grid!) as you complete your studies at Washington University. @Demoiselle
Can we start with the proposition that this is a free-speech zone? No one needs to prove their right to speak.
But we all learn that not every truth needs to be spoken. ("Do these pants make me look fat?") Some things can and perhaps should remain unsaid.
So which principle dominates at which moment? And who decides? 
Last question first. The backstop on who decides is, I very much regret to say, the emus. This, like a mall, is a seemingly public but technically private space.  The NYT owns it, even though we pay for its use via our subscriptions. They can shut it down.
But itchy trigger fingers lose customers. So does ill-tempered fractious wrangling among the locals. Fortunately for the NYT,  they're pushing an addictive substance. So they can give us a long leash.
Do we have the right or power to censor each other? Legally, probably not. But equally, we should use our speech considerately. No blanket condemnations, no evictions, no flouncing off in a huff. Just some reasoned expression of why what you said has affected me this way and, in reply, the same to explain why we didn't expect your response or, if we did, why we felt something more serious overrode the courteous regard for our shared space.
Good gray tedious compromise between reasoning people, boring though it may be, and a healthy dose of regret and recalibration all around.
